meanings.def: to operate a vehicle so that it goes in a particular direction
examples: Can you drive?
Don't drive so fast!
I drove to work this morning.
Shall we drive (= go there by car) or go by train?
drive something to drive a car/vehicle/truck/bus
He drives a taxi (= that is his job).
He was arrested for driving recklessly.
She drove quickly back to the office.
We drove from Quebec to Ottawa.
We must have driven over 600 kilometres today.
Driving lessons can be expensive.
We drove the rest of the way in silence.
Have you ever driven a racing car?
I learned to drive when I was 25.
They run a driving school in Birmingham.
Be sure not to drink and drive (= drive when you have drunk alcohol).
a ban on texting and driving
to drive home/​north
to drive safely

meanings.def: to take somebody somewhere in a car, taxi, etc.
examples: drive somebody + adv./prep. Could you drive me home?
My mother drove us to the airport.
They were driven to an unknown place in the hills.
drive somebody I don't want to take the bus. Will you drive me?
It’s too far to walk—I’ll take you by car.
Firefighters led the survivors to safety.
The president arrived, escorted by twelve bodyguards.
My mother drove us to the airport.
The attendant showed us to our seats.
He always walked her home.
Have you walked the dog yet today?
She guided us through the busy streets.
We were guided around the museums.
She ushered her guests to their seats.
A young woman directed them to the station.

meanings.def: to travel under the control of a driver
examples: A stream of black cars drove by.
A car drove up to us and a man got out.

meanings.def: to own or use a particular type of vehicle
examples: What car do you drive?
You need a special licence to drive a heavy goods vehicle.

meanings.def: to make somebody very angry, crazy, etc. or to make them do something extreme
examples: drive somebody + adj. to drive somebody crazy/mad/nuts/insane
drive somebody to do something Hunger drove her to steal.
drive somebody to something Those kids are driving me to despair.
The website was extremely slow, driving many users to distraction.
The situation has become so desperate that many are driven to suicide.
The destruction of the rainforest may drive certain species to extinction.

meanings.def: to force somebody to act in a particular way
examples: drive somebody + adv./prep. The urge to survive drove them on.
drive yourself + adv./prep. You're driving yourself too hard.
be driven by something He was driven by the desire to understand how things work.
The work is driven by the need for information sharing.

meanings.def: to provide the power that makes a machine work; to operate a device
examples: a steam-driven locomotive
The interface can be used to drive a printer.

meanings.def: to force somebody/something to move in a particular direction
examples: to drive sheep into a field
The enemy was driven back.

meanings.def: to influence something or cause it to make progress
examples: This is the main factor driving investment in the area.
A key factor driving growth was the launch of convenient products.
The dairy products market will also be driven by consumer demand.

meanings.def: to force something to go in a particular direction or into a particular position by pushing it, hitting it, etc.
examples: to drive a nail into a piece of wood
He took a wooden peg and drove it into the ground.
The knife had been driven through his heart.

meanings.def: to make an opening in or through something by using force
examples: They drove a tunnel through the solid rock.

meanings.def: to hit a ball with force, sending it forward
examples: to drive the ball into the rough (= in golf)

meanings.def: to carry something along
examples: Huge waves drove the yacht onto the rocks.

meanings.def: to fall or move rapidly and with great force
examples: The waves drove against the shore.

meanings.def: extremely clean, pure, etc.
to cause something to fail, for example a plan
to argue in an aggressive way and force somebody to agree on the best possible price or arrangement
to make somebody understand or accept something by saying it often, loudly, angrily, etc.
examples: You will really need to drive your point home.

meanings.def: to make somebody so worried, annoyed or upset that they lose control of their behaviour, especially by drinking too much alcohol
examples: The stress drove her to drink and put a strain on her marriage.
(humorous) Dragging kids through airports is enough to drive you to drink.

meanings.def: to make two people start disliking each other
examples: I don't want to drive a wedge between the two of you.
This was just one of the issues that drove a wedge between them.

meanings.def: to work so hard that you become extremely tired
the thing somebody is trying to say
examples: I wish I knew what they were driving at.

idioms.idiom: as clean, pure, etc. as the driven snow
drive a coach and horses through something

examples: I don't want to drive a wedge between the two of you.

meanings.def: a journey in a car or other vehicle
examples: Let's go for a drive.
a drive through the mountains
It's a three-hour drive to London.
It's one of the most scenic drives in Europe.
He was tired after the long drive home.
The lakes are only a short drive away.
He offered to take me for a drive later in the day.
It's a pleasant drive to the coast.
All my family live within an hour's drive.

meanings.def: the equipment in a vehicle that takes power from the engine to the wheels
examples: the drive shaft
a car with four-wheel drive
a left-/right-hand drive car (= a car where the driver and the controls are on the left/right)

meanings.def: a wide hard path or a private road that leads from the street to a house
examples: in/on the drive There were two cars parked in the drive.
He walked up the front drive of the vicarage.
A number of police cars blocked the drive.
He pulled into a long drive leading up to a large villa.

meanings.def: an organized effort by a group of people to achieve something
examples: The company is launching a big recruitment drive.
an export/economy drive
drive for something a drive for greater efficiency
drive to do something the government’s drive to reduce energy consumption
the campaign for parliamentary reform
an advertising campaign
She finally won the legal battle for compensation.
the endless battle between man and nature
the struggle for independence
the struggle between good and evil
the drive for greater efficiency
a drive to reduce energy consumption
the war against crime
Workers won their fight to stop compulsory redundancies.
a drive against corruption
the country's drive for modernization
a drive towards higher safety standards
The Popular Front spearheaded the drive for independence.
We organized a food drive for the city's homeless shelters.
From today, we're going on an economy drive.

meanings.def: a strong desire or need in people
examples: The treatment should not affect your sex drive or fertility.

meanings.def: a strong desire to do things and achieve something; great energy
examples: He'll do very well—he has tremendous drive.
We have this insatiable drive to be successful in the markets we serve.
He lacks the competitive drive needed to succeed.
You need to inject more narrative drive into the story.

meanings.def: a long hard hit or kick
examples: She has a strong forehand drive (= in tennis).
He scored with a brilliant 25-yard drive.
He hit a line drive straight at me.
Cole scored with a thunderous left-foot drive.

meanings.def: a type of computer storage that stores large amounts of data on a spinning (= turning) disk
examples: a CD drive

meanings.def: a social occasion when a lot of people compete in a game such as whist or bingo
an act of going after animals or the enemy and making them go into a smaller area, especially in order to kill or capture them
used in the names of roads
examples: 21 Island Heights Drive
